Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: Let me parse the process tree structure: 1. Root is a SEQUENCE: [receive_order, check_inventory, xor_node, close_order] 2. xor_node is an XOR (exclusive choice) between: - successful_subtree: PARALLEL of [authorize_payment, package_items, ship_order] - cancel_subtree: SEQUENCE of [cancel_order, close_order]

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: So if we take the cancel path: - receive_order - check_inventory - cancel_order - close_order (from cancel_subtree) - close_order (from root) That means Close_Order appears twice in the cancel path!

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Successful path: - receive_order - check_inventory - parallel(authorize_payment, package_items, ship_order) - close_order Since it's a PARALLEL operator, the children can execute in any order and can be interleaved.

Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: Standard flow should be: 1. Receive Order 2. Check Inventory 3. If sufficient: Authorize Payment, Package Items, Ship Order, then Close Order 4. If insufficient: Cancel Order, then Close Order

Name: Hypothesis Generation - PE
Text: Option 1: Receive_Order, Check_Inventory, Ship_Order, Package_Items, Authorize_Payment, Close_Order - Problem: Shipping before packaging and before payment authorization.

Name: Hypothesis Generation - PE
Text: Receive_Order, Check_Inventory, Cancel_Order, Close_Order, Close_Order - Problem: Close_Order appears twice

Name: Heuristic Reasoning - PE
Text: I think the shipping-before-payment is the most glaring domain violation.

Name: Backtracking - PE
Text: Ill go with the shipping trace.
